user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 14.3 is: Controlling expressions shall not be invariant.
Here are exceptions to this rule:
1. Invariants that are used to create infinite loops are permitted.
2. A do-while loop with an essentially Boolean controlling expression that evaluates to false and satisfies the constraints and semantics for an integer constant expression is permitted.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of MHD_create_thread_:
```c
int
MHD_create_thread_ (MHD_thread_handle_ID_ *handle_id,
                    size_t stack_size,
                    MHD_THREAD_START_ROUTINE_ start_routine,
                    void *arg)
{
#if defined(MHD_USE_POSIX_THREADS)
  int res;
#if defined(MHD_thread_handle_ID_get_native_handle_ptr_)
  pthread_t *const new_tid_ptr =
    MHD_thread_handle_ID_get_native_handle_ptr_ (handle_id);
#else  /* ! MHD_thread_handle_ID_get_native_handle_ptr_ */
  pthread_t new_tid;
  pthread_t *const new_tid_ptr = &new_tid;
#endif /* ! MHD_thread_handle_ID_get_native_handle_ptr_ */

  mhd_assert (! MHD_thread_handle_ID_is_valid_handle_ (*handle_id));

  if (0 != stack_size)
  {
    pthread_attr_t attr;
    res = pthread_attr_init (&attr);
    if (0 == res)
    {
      res = pthread_attr_setstacksize (&attr,
                                       stack_size);
      if (0 == res)
        res = pthread_create (new_tid_ptr,
                              &attr,
                              start_routine,
                              arg);
      pthread_attr_destroy (&attr);
    }
  }
  else
    res = pthread_create (new_tid_ptr,
                          NULL,
                          start_routine,
                          arg);

  if (0 != res)
  {
    errno = res;
    MHD_thread_handle_ID_set_invalid_ (handle_id);
  }
#if ! defined(MHD_thread_handle_ID_get_native_handle_ptr_)
  else
    MHD_thread_handle_ID_set_native_handle_ (handle_id, new_tid);
#endif /* ! MHD_thread_handle_ID_set_current_thread_ID_ */

  return ! res;
#elif defined(MHD_USE_W32_THREADS)
  uintptr_t thr_handle;
#if SIZEOF_SIZE_T != SIZEOF_UNSIGNED_INT

  mhd_assert (! MHD_thread_handle_ID_is_valid_handle_ (*handle_id));

  if (stack_size > UINT_MAX)
  {
    errno = EINVAL;
    return 0;
  }
#endif /* SIZEOF_SIZE_T != SIZEOF_UNSIGNED_INT */
  thr_handle = (uintptr_t) _beginthreadex (NULL,
                                           (unsigned int) stack_size,
                                           start_routine,
                                           arg,
                                           0,
                                           NULL);
  if ((MHD_thread_handle_native_) 0 == (MHD_thread_handle_native_) thr_handle)
    return 0;

  MHD_thread_handle_ID_set_native_handle_ (handle_id, \
                                           (MHD_thread_handle_native_) \
                                           thr_handle);

  return ! 0;
#endif
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function MHD_create_thread_:
#define MHD_USE_POSIX_THREADS 1
...
#define SIZEOF_SIZE_T 8
...
#define SIZEOF_UNSIGNED_INT 4
...
#define mhd_assert(ignore) ((void)0)
...
#define MHD_thread_handle_ID_is_valid_handle_(hndl_id) MHD_thread_handle_is_valid_((hndl_id).handle)
...
typedef pthread_t MHD_thread_handle_native_
...
#define MHD_thread_handle_ID_set_native_handle_(hndl_id_ptr, native_val) MHD_thread_handle_set_native_(&((hndl_id_ptr)->handle),native_val)
...
#define MHD_thread_handle_ID_set_invalid_(hndl_id_ptr) (MHD_thread_handle_set_invalid_(&((hndl_id_ptr)->handle)),MHD_thread_ID_set_invalid_(&((hndl_id_ptr)->ID)))
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
No runtime controlling expression in the provided function is invariant. Specific controlling expressions and why they need no further investigation: 
- if (0 != stack_size): depends on the function parameter stack_size, so not invariant.
- if (0 == res) (two occurrences): res is assigned from function calls (pthread_attr_init, pthread_attr_setstacksize, pthread_create) prior to being tested, so these conditions are not invariant.
- if (0 != res): likewise depends on res returned by pthread_create/pthread_attr_init and is not invariant.
- if (stack_size > UINT_MAX): depends on the parameter stack_size; not invariant.
- if ((MHD_thread_handle_native_) 0 == (MHD_thread_handle_native_) thr_handle): depends on thr_handle returned by _beginthreadex, so not invariant.

Preprocessor conditionals (#if defined(...), #elif) are compile-time, not runtime controlling expressions covered by MISRA C Rule 14.3. There are no loops (for/while/do-while) or switch statements with constant controlling expressions in the function. The mhd_assert macro is a no-op here and does not introduce an invariant controlling expression. Therefore there are no code fragments in this function that appear to violate MISRA C 2023 Rule 14.3.
